--- title: Neck and Head Regions subtitle: Musculoskeletal Overview --- ![Muscles of the Anterior Neck @OpenStaxAnatomyPhysiology2022](/The Archive/Images/OpenStax Anatomy and Physiology 2e/fig11.13 Muscles of the Anterior Neck.jpeg){#fig-openstax-fig11.13} ![Muscles of the Posterior and lateral neck @OpenStaxAnatomyPhysiology2022](/The Archive/Images/OpenStax Anatomy and Physiology 2e/fig11.14 Posterior and Lateral Views of the Neck.jpeg){#fig-openstax-fig11.14} ::: {.callout title="Reading list"} - Anatomy - Cervical osteology ch9 p329 @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017 - Examination - ch15 Screening the Head, Neck, and Back @heickGoodmanSnyderDifferential2023 - Manual Tx - ch30 Orthopaedic Manual Physical Therapy of the Cervical Spine and Temporomandibular Joint @wiseOrthopaedicManualPhysical2015 ::: # Segments The cervical spine can be divided into 3 segments: - Upper - Middle - Lower **Upper** consists of the first 2 cervical vertebrae: [atlas (C1)]({{< var ref-c1-bone.path >}}) and [axis (C2)]({{< var ref-c2-bone.path >}}). The **Middle** segments refer to [C3]({{< var ref-c3-bone.path >}})-[C6]({{< var ref-c6-bone.path >}}) and technically begins at the inferior surface of axis (C2) @jonesProjectFoundations2025. The **Lower segment** refers to the transition between the [last cervical vertebrae (C7)]({{< var ref-c7-bone.path >}}) and the [first thoracic vertebrae (T1)]({{< var ref-t1-bone.path >}}) @jonesProjectFoundations2025. # Movement - Rotation - Sidebend - Flexion - Extension # Rotation ## Pure rotation - atlanto-axial: Rotation + flexion - [Occipitoatlanto joint]({{< var ref-occipitoatlanto-joint.path >}}): Extension to offset the AA flexion @jonesProjectFoundations2025. # Joints | Joint | Extension | Flexion | Sidebend | Rotation | |-|-|-|-|-| | [Occipitoatlanto Joint]({{< var ref-occipitoatlanto-joint.path >}}) | 10° @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017

Muscle Origin Insertion Innervation Action
``` ::: ::: The [transversospinalis muscles]({{< var ref-transversospinalis-muscle-group.path >}}) run obliquely and medially from the transverse process of the inferior segment to the the spinous process of the superior segment @jonesProjectFoundations2025. **Unilateral** contraction creates contralateral rotation @jonesProjectFoundations2025. **Bilateral** contraction acts to cancel out rotation and create spine extension @jonesProjectFoundations2025. This extension accentuates the cervical lordosis created by the erector spinae @jonesProjectFoundations2025. This muscle group functions in spinal stability, proprioception, posture, and stabilization of the vertebral column @jonesProjectFoundations2025. The [SCM]({{< var ref-sternocleidomastoid.path >}}) can be seen as the "psoas of the neck" due to the fact it is commonly guarded or tight, but is rarely the cause of the overall dysfunction @jonesProjectFoundations2025. [Longissimus thoracis]({{< var ref-longissimus-thoracis.path >}}) should be considered when viewing the neck since its uppermost fibers overlap medially with the [iliocostalis cervicis]({{< var ref-iliocostalis-cervicis.path >}}) @jonesProjectFoundations2025. # Anatomy ## Intervertebral Disc (IVD) - 5x discs in C/S @duttonDuttonOrthopaedicExamination2020 - First IVD between C2 and 3 @duttonDuttonOrthopaedicExamination2020 :::{.callout-note} Named after vert above it @duttonDuttonOrthopaedicExamination2020 ::: The main dysfunction at the IVD is a [herniation]({{< var ref-cervical-disc-herniation.path >}}) # Kinematics ## Head Flexion **Osteokinematics**: Flexion: 45-50 deg **Arthrokinematics**: - Initial phase: begins in low c spine(C4-7) , - Second phase: occurs initially in C0-2 then c2-3, C3-4 - Flexion is described as an anterior osteokinematic rock (tilt) of the superior vertebra in the sag- ittal plane, a superoanterior glide of both superior facets of the zygapophyseal joints, and an anterior translation slide of the superior vertebra on the IVD - Uncovertebral joint: anterior spin @duttonDuttonOrthopaedicExamination2020 Restriction: Anterior osteokinematic motion restricted by: PLL, interspinous, lig flavum, and extensor mm ## Head Extension Arthrokinematics: - Posterior osteokinematic sagittal rock, an inferoposterior glide and approximation of the superior facets of the zygapophyseal joints, and a posterior translation of the vertebra on the disk. - Uncovertebral joint undergoes a posterior arthrokinematic spin osteokinematic motion of extension is restricted by anterior prevertebral mm and ALL ## Head Lateral SB Osteokinematics: Side bend: 40 deg :::{.callout-note} Sidebending: closer to 75 in supine because of hte muscles that limit SB with gravity: traps, scalenes, SCM (all are more lengthened in standing/sitting bc gravity pulling at insertions)(Harper 2023) ::: Arthrokinematics - Superoanterior glide of contra superior facet posteroinferior glide of ipsi facet - C/L translation of vertebra on disk - Inferomedial glide of ipsi uncovertebral joint, superolateral glide of contral uncovertebral joint Limited by contra scalenes, intertransverse ligs, facet jt motions limited by joint capsule and translation limited by IVD ## Head rotation Rotation 70-90 deg Virtually all rotation in UPPER C/S occurs between Atlas & Axis ### Arthrokinematics Muscles: Global neck mm: SCM and semispinalis capitis and splenius captius Local neck: longus captius and colli, semispinalis cervicis, multifidus longus colli and post neck mm for a sleeve that supports spinal segments during mvmt :::{.callout-tip} *same as sidebending motions ::: ## Coupled Motion - C0-C2: Opposite - C3-T3: Same - T4-L5: opposite :::{.callout-note} Coupled motion has been observed to change with age ::: # Joints ## OA Joint [Occipitoatlanto joint]({{< var ref-occipitoatlanto-joint.path >}}) OA joint Hypermobility is considered a diagnosis If range of rotation exceeds 8 degrees → stability testing necessary ## AA Joint [Atlantoaxial joint]({{< var ref-atlantoaxial-joint.path >}}) Pure axial rotation 60% of total rotation in CS is here # Kinematics ## Flexion Greatest at lower C/S (C5-C6) Least flexion at C2,3 ## Extension ## Rotation AA Joint performs pure axialrotation Rotation and SB are [coupled motions](#coupled-motion) ## Lateral flexion (SB) Rotation and SB [coupled motions](#coupled-motion) ## Coupled motion {#coupled-motion} Upper c spine: Sb and rotation — type 1 motion, OPPOSITE MOTION Regardless of posture Mid cervical: c3-c7 Same direction More type 1 motion: Changes in couple patterns :::{.callout-tip title="Clinical signifiance"} - If c spine motion is limited w sb and rotation to same side - 0 mid/lower c facet is suspected (restriction) - Assess A/PROM - Soft tissue ::: # Posture Cervical Lordosis - C4/5 is midpoint of curve - COG for skull is ant to foramen magnum # Dysfunction ## Vestibular and Visual symptoms - Upper c spine has more connections to vestib and visual systems than low c spine - So upper c spine dysfunction can cause more balance/visual disturbances ## Sensorimotor control :::{.callout-tip} Wearing a hard collar for 5 days has been shown to lead to altered eye mvmt control, increased postural sway and disturbed head neck awareness in healthy people @kristjanssonSensorimotorFunctionDizziness2009 ::: # Examination ## Screening :::{.callout title="Canada C-spine rules"} - Age >= 65 - Dangerous mech: - Fall from >=3 feet or 5 stairs - Axial load to head (ie diving) - MVC high speed >= 100 km/hr, 60 mph - Bike collision w object - Motorized rec vehicles - <= 45 deg of rotation - New onset of neural sx (paresthesias in extremities) ::: Warning signs of cervical region: - Subjective - Unexplained weight loss - SB away from painful side that causes pain (if this is the only motion causing pain) - Evidence of compromise of 2-3 spinal nerve roots - Pain - Gradual inc in pain - Expansion of pain in terms of the regions involved - Arm pain in pt younger than 35 or pt for more than 6 months - ROM: Spasms w PROM - Motor - painful/weak resistive testing - Limited scapular elevation - T1 palsy (weakness / atrophy of the intrinsic mm of hand) - Visual disturbances - Hoarseness - Horner syndrome– - VBI and cervical myelopathy ## ROM - Upper C/S isolate rotation - Cervical rotation Full Flexion # Special Tests - [VBI Test]({{< var ref-VBI-vertebrobasilar-insufficiency-test.path >}}) - [Sharp-Purser Test]({{< var ref-sharp-purser-test.path >}}) - [Alar Ligament Test]({{< var ref-alar-ligament-test.path >}}) - Tectorial Membrane integrity - [Spurling's Test]({{< var ref-spurlings-test.path >}}) - TOS - [Allen's Maneuver]({{< var ref-tos-allen-maneuver.path >}}) (*should be performed before other TOS tests*) - [CRLF Test (Lindgren's test)]({{< var ref-cervical-rotation-lateral-flexion-test.path >}}) - [Adson's Test]({{< var ref-tos-adsons-vascular-test.path >}}) (TOS) - [ROOS Test]({{< var ref-tos-roos-stress-test.path >}}) - Canadian C-Spine Rules ## Provocative tests - Disk herniation - Vertebral end plate fracture - Vertebral body fracture # Evaluation - 1st Rib mobility - Shoulder mobility - Vertebra mobility # Evaluation inventory ## Supine - Spinous processes - Alignment - Depth - A flat portion between segments is indicative of a tight/contracted muscle in that area bringing those segments together - Suboccipital release - If you cannot perform the release, loosening other things and returning to it would be a valid test-retest @jonesProjectFoundations2025. - Sidebend mobility at each segment (compare R to L) - Suboccipital opening (sidebend + rotation) - Head pivoting on cervical spine ## Supine with Flexed head Bring the head into flexion and keep it there using your chest. - Palpate cervical and head extensors # Manual Treatment - Suboccipital release - Work on each suboccipital individually - PA Glides - Upglides - Downglides - STM + Trap stretch - STM + Levator scap stretch - STM Scalenes - STM + scalene stretch - SCM STM - ULTTs - ULTT 1 - ULTT 2a - ULTT 2b - ULTT 3 # Exercises - DNF - Shoulder Y, W, Ts - Hemi Should Y,W, T, WER with cervical retraction # Cervical Radiculopathy Wainner et al 2003 Cervical radiculoapthy diagnostic tests - Positive ULTT1 (median nerve) - Involved sign cervical rotation range of motion < 60 deg Positive distraction test - Positive spurlings test - 4/4 = 99 % specific, 30 x more likely to have cervical radiculopathy - ¾ = 94% specific, 6 x more likely to have cervical radiculopathy # DDX Reproduction of Pain with Cervical Distraction - Spinal lig tear - Annulus fibrosis (AF) Tear or inflammation - Mm spasm - Large disk herniation - Dural irritability Compression - Arthritis - Nerve root irritation - Herniation - Vert end plate fx - vertebral body fx Bearing down - Reproduction of pain = C/s herniation # Pain ::: {.callout} - Clinical Considerations of Head and Neck Pain @donnellyTravellSimonsSimons2019 -
